transcript:
Therapist: Let's dive into exploring how your family dynamics might be impacting your thoughts and beliefs about yourself. Can you tell me more about your experiences growing up and how they may have contributed to your struggles with self-worth?

Patient: Well, my parents were always very critical of me. Nothing I did was ever good enough for them. They would constantly compare me to my siblings and point out my flaws. I always felt like I was disappointing them.

Therapist: That sounds like a very painful experience, Jamie. It's understandable how those early experiences could shape your beliefs about yourself. Let's use the downward arrow technique to uncover some of the core beliefs that may have developed from those experiences. If your parents were constantly critical of you, what did that make you believe about yourself?

Patient: It made me believe that I'm not good enough, no matter how hard I try. That I'll always be a disappointment.

Therapist: And if that belief were true, what would that mean about you as a person?

Patient: It would mean that I'm fundamentally flawed, that there's something wrong with me.

Therapist: And if there was something fundamentally wrong with you, what would that mean for your future and your relationships?

Patient: It would mean that I'm destined to fail, that I'll never be able to have healthy relationships or be successful in life.

Therapist: Thank you for being so open and vulnerable, Jamie. We've identified a core belief that "I'm not good enough" and an intermediate belief that "If I'm not good enough, I'm destined to fail and be alone." These beliefs likely developed from your experiences with your family and are contributing to your current struggles with depression and self-worth.
